summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to authorize a subpoena to the law firm Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP (BSF) for most of her requests. The order finds Maxwell's subpoena requests overly broad, insufficiently specific, and not meeting the legal standards for pre-trial production under Rule 17(c). The court reserves judgment on three requests pending government input.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, seeking to subpoena documents from the law firm BSF for her defense and pending suppression motions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, analyzing and ruling on Maxwell's motion for a subpoena and the government's related request.

connections.description: Maxwell seeks to subpoena the law firm BSF, which has represented alleged victims in civil litigation related to Epstein, and the firm opposed the subpoena.

events.title: Court Order on Subpoena Motion
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to authorize a Rule 17(c) subpoena to Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP for most requests, reserving judgment on three.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell sought court authorization to subpoena the law firm Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP (BSF) for twelve categories of documents.

The court denied authorization for Requests 1-8 and 12, finding them overly broad, insufficiently specific, and failing to meet the legal standard from United States v. Nixon for pre-trial production.
The court reserved judgment on Requests 9-11, ordering the Government to provide its views on their propriety within one week.
The Government's request for a blanket ruling entitling it to notice of all future subpoenas was denied, though the court noted it would typically consider government briefing.

Maxwell's theories for needing the documents (e.g., for impeachment, to show government coordination) were largely rejected as speculative, premature, or improper attempts to use Rule 17(c) as a discovery tool.
